prompt.p: Coordination of growth factors for haemopoiesis is controlled by hormones and their interaction with specific receptors.
What is a function of interleukin 3 (IL3)?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Acts with other growth factors on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets
Targeted at monocyte growth and development

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Acts with other growth factors on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets) is Correct. Interleukin 3 (IL3) acts with other growth factors on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets.

tr.td:
In the fetus: helps haematopoietic cells move from yolk sac to liver and then bone marrow
After birth: needed at all stages for normal blood cell production
with other growth factors acts on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets
like IL3 but acts to produce neutrophils, eosinophils and monocytes
similar to GM-CSF but directed mainly at producing neutrophils
targeted at monocyte growth and development

modalFeedback.p:
Table 12.2 Growth factors and their function.
Taken from: Naish et al: Basic Medical Sciences 1E
Option B (Directed at producing neutrophils) is Incorrect. Granulocyte stimulating factor (G-CSF) is directed at producing neutrophils.
Option C (Responsible for erythroid development) is Incorrect. Erythropoietin (EPO) is responsible for erythroid development.
Option D (Responsible for megakaryocytic development) is Incorrect. Thrombopoietin (TPO) is responsible for megakaryocytic development.
Option E (Targeted at monocyte growth and development) is Incorrect. Monocyte stimulating factor (M-CSF) is targeted at monocyte growth and development.

Option A (Acts with other growth factors on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets) is Correct. Interleukin 3 (IL3) acts with other growth factors on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets.

tr.td:
In the fetus: helps haematopoietic cells move from yolk sac to liver and then bone marrow
After birth: needed at all stages for normal blood cell production
with other growth factors acts on early progenitors to produce mature red cells, granulocytes, monocytes and platelets
like IL3 but acts to produce neutrophils, eosinophils and monocytes
similar to GM-CSF but directed mainly at producing neutrophils
targeted at monocyte growth and development

Table 12.2 Growth factors and their function.
Taken from: Naish et al: Basic Medical Sciences 1E
Option B (Directed at producing neutrophils) is Incorrect. Granulocyte stimulating factor (G-CSF) is directed at producing neutrophils.
Option C (Responsible for erythroid development) is Incorrect. Erythropoietin (EPO) is responsible for erythroid development.
Option D (Responsible for megakaryocytic development) is Incorrect. Thrombopoietin (TPO) is responsible for megakaryocytic development.
Option E (Targeted at monocyte growth and development) is Incorrect. Monocyte stimulating factor (M-CSF) is targeted at monocyte growth and development.
